thread.title: Everything you need to know about tonight's lunar eclipse - Irish Independent
thread.title_full: Everything you need to know about tonight's lunar eclipse - Irish Independent

title: Everything you need to know about tonight's lunar eclipse - Irish Independent
text:
Everything you need to know about tonight's lunar eclipse Independent.ie Stargazers in Ireland will be treated to a partial eclipse tonight. http://www.independent.ie/irish-news/everything-you-need-to-know-about-tonights-lunar-eclipse-35441381.html A partial solar eclipse is seen behind the 9th-century Prambanan Temple in Yogyakarta, Indonesia (AP) Stargazers in Ireland will be treated to a partial eclipse tonight. Share Everything you need to know about tonight's lunar eclipse Independent.ie Stargazers in Ireland will be treated to a partial eclipse tonight. http://www.independent.ie/irish-news/everything-you-need-to-know-about-tonights-lunar-eclipse-35441381.html 
February's full moon will grow a little darker and appear as a deep red. 
The eclipse will begin at 10.32pm and peak at 12.34am. 
The phenomenon appears when the sun, Earth and moon are aligned with the earth in the middle. The moon's surface will shine because it is reflecting the sun's rays. 
The spectacle should be visible across Ireland, as well as most of North and South America, Europe, Africa and most of Asia. 
Although less spectacular than a total lunar eclipse, or a Blood Moon, people nationwide should be able to get a good glimpse with Met Eireann forecasting a clear, cold night. 
The penumbral eclipse is often mistaken for a normal Full Moon but, according to Astronomy Ireland, the next total lunar eclipse will be visible from Ireland on January 21st, 2019. 
Those lucky enough to own binoculars or a telescope can also keep an eye out for the New Year comet, which will also be visible in our skies tonight. 
The comet will be 7.4 million miles away, the closest it's been to Ireland since 2011. 
Temperatures are set to drop to below minus three degrees tonight with severe frost and icy patches. 
Brace yourself for the weekend, as Saturday will be very cold with highest temperatures of four to six degrees. 
There will be coastal showers with the possibility of hail storms. 
Sunday will again be cold with coastal showers and temperatures between four and six degrees. Online Editors
